text: Just wondering what everyone's schedule/wake windows look like with their 5 month olds 🥰 my guy is still waking every 3-4 hours at night so looking for tips throughout the day to get him to sleep better at night.

comments.text: He looks like a very healthy baby. So I'd say he will continue feeding frequently. Ensure he feeds every 3 hours during the day to keep calorie intake up.

replies.text: Natasha Chant I was gonna say the same! Lol. My chunk still wakes up so much at night🤣they’re just hungry.

comments.text:
My little one is 6 months as was doing the same
3 days ago I decided it was time to move her into her own room, we have had the whole bath bottle bed routine for quite a while and she has mostly settled well though would wake every 3 hours
Since being in her room
Day one was tough-
she settled at 7/8 ish (Normally would be 6) and was quite unsettled but then woke at 11 and again at 2
Day two she settled after bath and bottle at 6pm slept till 11 I changed her bum and gave her a bottle and then she slept till 6:30! I can’t remember the last time I had a WHOLE 6 hours sleep
It’s not easy letting them settle themselves as she occasionally wakes a little and yesterday she didn’t nap in the day was that was tough but I feel you kind of have to be cruel to be kind
Good-luck xx

Mine slept through from just a few weeks old i was truly blessed however he’s now teething and he’s all over the place. One thing I would recommend doing is bath bottle bed at the same time every night. White noise if u havnt already tried that. And maybe an extra ounce in the bed time bottle too. Maybe he’s hungry still he’s a big boy like mine and that’s what I did for him he slept like a dream before teething. Also told someone else on here to do that and the next day she messaged saying he slept through the night good luck 🙌🏻

Mine is 5 months and has been sleeping 10.5 hours each night. I keep him very active during the day and let him nap when needed. He uses a Walker, jumper and we do tummy time/ entertainment activity floor mat. He also eats baby food and some regular food. He sleeps well now.

Honestly, I had a big baby also. She just turned 1 yr a few days ago and slept through the night for the first time the two nights following her bday. They just need the calories! He will sleep longer when he is ready but I think that is perfectly normal for now. Hang in there!

replies.text: P.s after the two days she is still back to waking up to eat🤦‍♀️🤷‍♀️. It was nice while it lasted.

comments.text: Everyone is different but my five month old is on a schedule of 2 hours for wake windows for her naps we are doing 2- 1.5 hour naps then a 45 at the end of the day, the huckleberry app sucks to keep track of everything but their sleep samples are the best! I highly recommend a google search for them❤️❤️

Sleep 7pm-7am, Bottle when he wakes at 7am, solids at 8am. Monica Clarke-Sather Routine routine routine! It's so crucial to get a baby on a good schedule. I make sure I feed my 3 month old every 3-4 hours during the day so he doesn't feel like he needs to catch on up eating at night. We have the same routines during the day I give him plenty of Tummy time, play, fresh air/sun outside and brain stimulation to tire him out. He takes 1-3 naps a day. Then around 8pm we settle down, do quite time, he gets his last feeding, a clean diaper, body & face wiped down, clean clothes, I put him in a sleep sack, turn his sound machine on then I rock him to sleep after that i transfer him to his crib. He sleeps 10 hours through the night bed time to morning. I never tried to sleep train him, I just kept up a routine and around 1-1½ months he started sleeping through the night. He knows once quite time starts and we start our night time routine that it's time for bed.

text:
Hey y’all, I feel like this needs to be said because I’ve been seeing a lot of posts about sleep training at a VERY young age, moms upset because of their babies waking up so often, the whole works! Mind you- everyone is entitled to their own opinion, you can agree to disagree with me, this is NOT me mom shaming or coming at anyone, this is coming from a place of love and support, and whether you decide to take this advice or not is totally up to you!
•Newborns usually are going to wake often. Their tummies are so small and for about the first 6 weeks, they just want to bond with you, and be reassured they have that trust and security with you.
•if you are concerned they’re waking up more than they should or can’t seem to settle after you put them back to sleep, look into reflux, gas, food sensitivities, tongue ties, or their sleep environment (temp of room, dark or too much light, white noise, what they’re sleeping in/on, etc)
•some will argue sleep training is acceptable at all ages. From things I have read, researched, and the multiple professional opinions I have gotten, sleep training is only beneficial starting as young as 4 months, when your baby is able to differentiate days and nights, connect sleep cycles, produce natural melatonin, and have an established bond with mom/dad.
•there are quite a few different sleep training methods, CIO is not your only option!! I urge y’all to Google and read up on the different methods because what works for one baby might not work for yours!
Motherhood is none the less exhausting. It brings out the best and the worst in us. Please know if you feel you are at your wits end, it is 100% okay to put baby in a safe spot and take a breather. We are only human, it’s okay to feel the emotions I’m sure all of us do and have felt.
Seriously, Google has been my best friend, the pediatrician’s office knows me on a first name basis, my mom is probably on the verge of blocking my number because I call her SO much lol, and I have probably ordered about 5 different books and read them all twice. Don’t get discouraged about posts you see, every baby is different! Mine was sleeping through the night and then in an instant I got humbled with the notorious ✨4 month sleep regression✨ it happens!! Everyone drink some water and hang in there lol

comments.text: i agree, my baby is 10 weeks old and I let her sleep when she wants to sleep and I can say I am very lucky cause she ain't fussy and she sleeps from 9pm til 4am and it don't take her long to sleep after feeding her at 4am then she wakes up at 9am again. I honestly dread the 4 month regression but I am mentally prepared for it let's see how it goes 😅

replies.text: April Willis I truly hope your 4mo sleep regression isn’t as bad as ours was. During the day it was every 30 minutes and at night was every 1.5hrs 😭 no one can prepare for that kind of insanity. Prior to this he was sleeping 10hrs at night so it was devastating

comments.text: I appreciate this post. With my first I tried a bit too hard to put her into a schedule , sleep training and EASY routine. With my second who is 7ish weeks old I also first tried the same thing and the same negative reactions happened. Now I just go with the flow and try my best to be there for both of the children. And I have slowly found some peace for my mind. Of course there are ups and downs but at the end of the day I am grateful and content.

This time around has been a little easier just because I am more relaxed about everything and don’t have expectations regarding sleep.

comments.text: Love! Emphasis on the sleep training. You are not limited to CIO & Ferber or any method of letting your baby cry! There’s tooonnnss of sleep training techniques that are baby friendly that work just as well. Our baby is 4.5 months and hit the regression a few weeks ago. Our doctor gave us advice that’s works amazing! I breastfeed and put to bed at her regular bedtime (8:30-9), then wake for a top off feed right before I go to sleep (10-10:30) and we’ve stretched out until 4-5am before needing another feed then back to sleep until 7:30am. We only wake once a night which is great, no crying required, and our hope is that she will eventually cut out the 4am wake once she no longer needs night feeds.

💯 the first 3 months is referred to as the 4th trimester because you and baby are just learning and adapting to them being newly in the world. Take it slow and bond with each other at this stage. You have plenty of time to get settled into a routine. ❤️❤️❤️

Great post! The first few months are very difficult and ever changing. What worked best for me was splitting the night up with my husband. He was on baby duty from 9pm to 1am. I had pumped milk for him to bottle feed. It helped me get at least one decent stretch of sleep during the night and something to look forward to towards the end of the day. I went into another room, turned a fan on high and snoozed.

I got my baby on a schedule asap and couldn't believe it when it started working. I was a ftm and the schedule, while it was working, also made me a slave to it and stressed me out when one nap would go wrong.... So much info out there that we can forget to just be with them.

I was 100% this mom as a ftm. I thought my infant could be sleep trained. I have embraced the little sleep I get and even at almost 5 months, I get up and make him a bottle in the middle of the night. His naps are no longer than 2 hours a day, his last nap is between 20min and 1 hour and then bedtime is about 9pm. He slept through the night Sunday but here we are and he had a full diaper and a warm bottle and back to sleep. I only get this 1x so I just embrace it.

My biggest pet peeve is when "friends" tell me, let him cry it out or you'll spoil him by going to him when he cries. My son only cries when he needs something. I have put distance between me and those "friends"

Yes … my little angel was sleeping the night then the 4 month regression / leap happened and we’ve recently gotten back after a couple weeks to typically waking once a night for a feed. I’m hopeful to get back to sleeping through the night but for now, we adjust and give him what he needs. ❤️🙏

I’ve been told to “just let my baby cry she’ll soon fall asleep” “you can’t keep going in to pick her up when she’s crying she’ll always be used to it”

I’ve always tended to her needs if she’s upset or fussing I’m there if she needs feeding I’m there if she needs just a cuddle to help settle and to know I’m there I’ll do it” couldn’t imagine just letting her go and cry herself to sleep it would break my heart.

Luckily I don’t know if it’s because I’ve always been there she knows now and will settle so much better her naps are good she’ll settle easily and go sleep knowing I’ll be there if she needs me and at night she goes down at 7.40-6am and sleeps without waking (maybe a odd time if she wants her dummie or maybe a little food and goes right down” she’s such a good baby and I think it’s us who contribute to that. I know all babies are not the same but for my baby she always knows mummy is there and mummy will always tend to my needs if so so she’s just a settled baby now and she has been since 3 months and is gaining well so I’m not worried about her going without a bottle during the night 💓👶🏻

Ughh mine is 6 months and is worse off sleeping more than ever before. He’s eating more and waking more at night now than when he was a newborn. Probably wakes about 4-9 times a night and is up for good at the crack of sunlight. I’m beyond exhausted, I even called out of work today for the first time in 8 months. I’m feeling depressed, anxious and more sleep deprived than ever. I just want my child to sleep, even if he wakes 3 times a night if he happy.

I agree, I don’t believe that babies can be sleep trained until 4-6 months depending on birth story, prematurity, etc… what you can do however, is give your baby some good habits to start working on and a consistent pattern. Follow their wake windows, place down somewhat drowsy instead of nursing or feeding to sleep. These will help later on if a mom does decide to sleep train. A newborn can’t be on a set schedule that is 100% true. ❤️

It's just their personality and needs. You can read 1 million things on here and it won't change the fact your baby had their own individual needs.
Relax, follow your babies cues, embrace their personality and needs and stop trying to fit them into a text book box.

text:
Hey guys,
My little is 7 weeks old and I need some advice as a FTM.
He currently eats every 2 hours in the day time. He eats 2-3 ounces each time. At night if he’s asleep he’ll go 3-4 before waking up for a bottle. Is it something I’m doing wrong as to why he’s eating every 2 hours still or is that ok?

He also fights his sleep so much. He’ll nap during the day after bottles, but not very well and at night sometimes he’s up for hours not wanting to sleep or having trouble getting into a deep sleep.

We’re currently not on any set schedule, we just go by when he’s tired/hungry and let him tell us what he needs. Mainly because idk how to get a baby on a schedule? Lol if he’s not tired at a nap time or is tired when it isn’t what do I do? Lastly, how do I help him differentiate between a nap and bedtime?

Sorry if these questions seem silly I’m just at such a loss because again, I’m a first time mom and he was in the nicu until almost 4 weeks so it feels like I missed out on establishing things early. 😞 TIA

comments.text: It would help taking into account "awake times" appropriate for his age..sometimes you read tiredness on babies when they are actually overtired ..and overtiredness brings sleep problems. It's hard to set a schedule at 7 weeks old but little by little you're gonna make it. Feeding every 2h its ok.
My LO is 6 weeks and eats every 3-4 hours 4 oz. and sometimes gets 5 oz. Her afternoon naps are horrible but she sleeps through the night

replies.text: Ariane Pudney same here with my 6 week old
Ariane Pudney mine is 8 weeks and does the same

My baby will be 8 weeks on Wednesday and during the day she takes 3/4 oz every two hours and at night usually goes 4/5 hours in between feedings. I was so concerned with her still eating every two hours but my pediatrician said since she’s not overweight or underweight and seems healthy, too just keep doing what I’m doing. FTM here too!
My baby is 7 weeks and does same! Eats every 2 hrs in day, and will go 3-4 at night! Seems normal!

Oh my goodness he’s the cutest little guy!!!!!!!! He looks so healthy and happy!!! Congratulations

comments.text: I am going through the same with my 7 week old daughter. She feeds every hour 🫣, i had the same doubts as you but I got paediatric + plunket nurses’ help, been trying to get her on a schedule for the past two days, it’s been very hard but it may work for us in due course

Everything you mentioned is normal. Literally everything. Just listen to baby and make sure you set a decent bed time between 6-8pm and wake up between 6-9am. Those times really vary on the baby. As long as baby is hitting those growth charts fine you are doing it all right.

We followed the babywise schedule with mine you can find them online for ages - the main difference that helped mine was feed upon waking - mine slept better after digestion but laying down right after eating was worse because of reflux so that just worked better and at night we fed before bed but upright for 30 min then laid down

My baby is 6 weeks today and I just started trying to establish a bedtime. I noticed she got fussier around 9-10pm so I will just stay with her in our bedroom, turn off all lights and sounds and bounce her to sleep. It helps.

Breastmilk has melatonin at night and cortisol in the morning so it helps babies get circadian rhythm. If can’t breastfeed then in the morning when he wakes up open curtains and go outside into the light. Then naps with curtains open. At night keep lights low. It takes some time but he will get into the circadian rhythm. Then small feeds in the middle of the night and straight back to sleep. Keeps lights low while feeding at night. Only enough light for you to see while feeding. Then try to entertain lots during the day.
It's okay that's he eats every 2 hours. That's when we would feed each baby at the daycare I worked for.
My 3.5 month old eats 6 oz and about every 2/3 hours. He takes one big nap during the day but then car naps the rest but sleeps through the night!

We upped my babies milk- If he'll take more, try that. We also started with a bedtime which is the best thing we have done because we were keeping our baby up with us until 11ish and shifting her asleep up to bed. Now she goes to bed anywhere between 8 and 9, regardless if she's awake and she eventually falls asleep. She's 11 weeks now and has been going from then until about 4/half 4. X
My daughter is 7 weeks old as well and eats 2-3 oz every two hours and goes til 3 hours at night. You’re doing just fine momma!
Normal!!! I think I bumped my guy up to 4 oz. at about 6 weeks, but he is kinda chunky. He ate about the same and gave us the same 3-4 hour intervals at night.

So adorable!

He naps well during the day and at night but also is a noisy sleeper so it doesn’t sound like he is in a deep sleep…he was 6 weeks premature and I heard that it’s a preemie thing.
May be time to increase his ounces per bottle! He might sleep better at night!

comments.text: I fed my kid every 2 hours until he started eating solids and then slowly from there I started taking away a feeding at a time. So do it as long as he needs.. As long as u don't have an issue with it.. There is no issue with it

Girl cherish that!!! When my son was that little he would “skip a feeding” at night and sleep longer. He STILL does!! He’s 16 weeks old and sleeps 8 hours at night and goes 4 hrs during the day in between feeds! You’re doing great mama!! I never set a schedule either he got into one on his own!

Enjoy every minute. Build every bond you can and let them be strong. All i can suggest is learning your baby's sleep cues and start putting them down for naps so you don't develope a habit of letting him get overtired. Literally putting them in their crib or bassinet to sleep is good too, for some of the times so they can get used to it. Biggest mistake I think I made with my girl (16 weeks now) was holding her. ALL. THE. TIME. I loved every second. We just started sleep training and it is hell. Hell going from jumping to their every cry immediately then all of a sudden not. The worst, most confusing thing for them why you don't pick them up. Im not sure this is the best path for us yet. But we are trying it out.

At two months, my pediatrician said my baby should be producing melatonin and we should start to establish a bedtime routine. Make sure your little one gets outside a good amount during the day. The sun on his skin will help him establish a day/night schedule. I tried to stick to the normal wake periods during the day with naps too. Then around seven-ish in the evening, we do a bath (don’t use soap everyday, but warm water feels good), oil his skin and do a little massage, then let him play and sing a little song to him or whatever sounds good to you, and then I rock him to sleep. If he wakes up and it has been two hours or more, I fed him in a dark quiet room and rocked him back to sleep. He started to stretch out his feedings and got the hang of it. He fluctuates some one waking, but it is usually once or twice a night now. Good luck. You are doing great. My baby hates to go to sleep, but I have gotten better at putting him down and knowing when and how to get him to sleep. He is 5 months now.

Just get a good routine that works for you going. At his age (my lil guy is 10 weeks) but still can only handle being awake like an hour to and hour and a half. If he goes last that it’s much more difficult for him to get to sleep. We have followed a routine since he was about 3 weeks old. And that seems to have helped my guy (my first son I never had a routine knew nothing of wake windows and he was so much harder to get to sleep) I also have since 2 weeks old swaddled him for naps and night time sleep so when he’s ready and getting tired I swaddle him then feed him and it seems to let him know it’s time for sleep. I also have a sound machine that I do lullabies on for naps and white noise for bed time. I feel like doing bath time routine and the white noise let’s him know it’s time for sleep at night. Also right at 7 weeks my guy was still eating every 2hrs and I was given advice to just fit an extra ounce in with his feeding and it made such a difference! So that could help as well as just setting a solid routine to show sleep time from wake time.
Sorry, I’m not helpful with advice but gosh he is so cute!

I use the Nara app to help me track when he’s awake and asleep. I try and get him to relax and then fall asleep by using the 5 S’s (swaddle, side-laying, swaying, sucking and sound) shortly before when the app says his next nap should be. I haven’t taken the taking cara babies class but a friend told me that her approach is that it’s not our job to make the baby sleep it’s our job to provide the opportunity for sleep. So I do all 5 S’s and lay him in the bassinet or wherever I’m going to have him sleep and then I walk away for a bit and see what happens.

I think you’re doing just fine. Sounds exactly like what we did with our baby boy. I breastfed him on demand usually every 2 hours or sometimes earlier. It’s hard to put a baby this small on a set schedule, so going off his cues is exactly what I would do. For him to differentiate nap and bedtime have a bedtime routine that you do. For example ours has always been bath, lotion, read a book, breastfeed, then bed. It just kind of helps them realize that it’s bedtime after doing those certain things. Also, he could still have his days and nights mixed up. So what we always did was keep everything bright and loud during the daytime to show him that we’re up and going, then at nighttime we have everything very dark and quiet with his noise machine on!
My girl is 2.5m and still eats every 2-3 hrs in the day time. You're doing just fine!

I went back to work 4 weeks ago and let our “routine” form itself as the days went by. Also, we use a sleep sack at bedtime and don’t nap where we sleep at night and i believe that’s helped.

comments.text: Try a nested bean swaddle or Merlin’s magic sleep suit saved my sanity. Also yeah let him eat when he is hungry no harm

Your little guy might be a bit hungry, maybe up the feed amount a little and see if he goes a longer stretch but each baby is different and a 2- 3 hour stretch is about right at this stage. If he vomits a lot after upping the feed then he has probably over eaten.. babies are piggies and will sometimes just eat because it's on offer. Also see if baby is maybe confusing night time with day time. I make sure my baby's room is very dark at night and very light in the day so he knows the difference. In the morning I open the curtains and switch on a radio for some extra background noise and i speak and interact with him during feeds and nappy changes and I don't swaddle in the daytime. At night I swaddle and switch off the radio. I also don't speak or Interact with him during the night feeds and changes so he doesn't think its time to be awake and alert. I don't use a lot of light, only a small white camping light to see during nappy changes and then I have a red camping light which is less disturbing for baby which I use just so see the basics in the night. At night I feed my son in his cot, I sit him up and feed him his bottle and burp in the same position. When he was a newborn I found that the ritual of taking him out of the cot to a feeding chair and then feeding and burping left him too awake after a feed on the middle of the night which resulting in spending time trying to put him back to sleep which meant even less sleep for me. With the cot feeding I am able to feed him and lay him back down in the warmth of his cot, swaddle and leave the room. He chats to himself for a short while and then goes back to sleep. When i change his nappy In the night I do it in the middle of the feed so he has the rest of the bottle to come back to before I swaddle for sleep again. This is probably all unconventional and against the 'rules' but it's what works for me. The main thing is for you to figure out what works for you - even if it seems weird. Try different things until it works. You are doing a super job, just keep at it. Good Luck! Xx

text:
Hi all, very tired mum, looking for some advice!
My little girl Arwen is 4 months old (3 months adjusted age) she has never been a good sleeper. She has always resisted naps- the longest naps she's had is around 45 mins and stretch of sleep she's had through the night is around 3-4hours. She's breast fed during the day and night and bottle fed with breastmilk in the early evening by my husband. Her routine is: awake, fed, changed, massage, dress and play at 08:00, I try my best to get her to nap around 09:30/10:00 when she is acting tired but she either resists completely or does a micro contact nap. If she does nap she will not be put down awake, I have to transfer her from me into her Moses basket. I then try the same routine around lunchtime when she seems tired again (12/13:00ish after being fed, changed, play etc.) And again around 15:30/16:00. At around 18:00 she is fed then gets a lavender bath at 18:30. She then gets a lavender lotion massage and is fed again with a bedtime story. Up until about 2 weeks ago she would scream with colic for an hour at this point but be asleep by 8pm and sleep until a dream feed at midnight then 03:30 and again at 05:30. She would breastfeed, need changed and go back to sleep pretty easily during wake-ups. But now she is screaming for hours, asleep by 9pm, wakes around 3 times before midnight and is up every 2 hours. She also is harder to get back to sleep. At nighttime the room is dark with red light, an ok temperature, she has lush sleepy spray in her crib and white noise playing all night. She sleeps in a normal babygrow with a light tog sleep bag as she's very warm blooded like us! She sleeps in her co sleeper crib next to the bed. She's never been a big eater and is small however is following her curve. The paediatrician says she is a snacker but is very efficient on the boob (can get 2-3 ounces out in the 5 mins she latches) she also only drinks 2-3 ounces at a time from the bottle. She's great at self soothing with sucking her thumb, doesn't use a dummy and hates being swaddled including the Merlin magic suit. I personally would like to wait until the 4 month sleep regression is over with before sleep training and don't agree with the crying it out method. She has silent reflux which she has infant gaviscon for in case its relevant. I realise this is a rant but any advice is much appreciated. We are so tired and know that she needs the sleep as much as us! Thank you ❤️

comments.text: Sleep regressions are different for each baby, so I agree this might be an earlier sleep regression for her, even though she is 3months adjusted. Honestly you seem to be doing everything right, maybe this is just something that takes time to pass? Anything you're having in your diet that might be making the colic worse?

I didn't read everything, I got a good away thru. Up to saying she wake 3 times before midnight, so I went back to see the age and yupp my thought lines up with age. Your going thru a sleep regression babe. The 4 month one. So all this is normal.

Sorry to hear!

I think Ferbers Method would help you. You do you bedtime routine. Amd you do all the things you normally do. Then feed her. And when just about asleep I lay down. Well, with.my son I would let him fall to sleep and then lay him down. And he would open his eyes and wake for few moments but hopefully at least the goal is for them to close them again and drift off.
However, when he starts crying. You wait 3 mins the 1st night the 1st time. Rhen go in and check on babe. You leave them down. And don't pick them up mostly. Some mommas I've seen them say they do actually pick up their babe. But so, then you sooth and calm.down. and lay them down for bed and leave, then you wait for them to ve crying 5mins.
And repeat the same process.
And again at 8mon.
And 12mon and 15mins. And ect.
I lean in over crib rails and love on him he tends to stand ans I just lean in and love on him. I kiss his head and pat his bum and rub his back. And I same simple short phrases for him to start associating to sleep with.

Then over the night if he wakes I will feed unless it's ridiculous the amount of time he hasn't let gone by after his last feed or something alike. Once fed, or not feed, and laid back down, and sleeping for a period of time to indicate has gone to bed. Then, if he wakes and crys again,, I start up again with Ferbers, starting at 5min for the 1st time and going in to try and calm him. And then repeat w adding in 3 mins or however you choose to do it
It's the Ferbers Method.
It's a more gentle CIO way.

Also! So, babes that wake that frequently I believe have trouble with the transition from the end of 1 sleep cycle and the start of the next sleep cycle. They wake during the transition and then unable to get back to sleep independently.

sleep training is NOT the magic way to get them to sleep thru the night. That IMO, has more to do with day time sleeping hours and wake windows. And alot of babes still need to eat thru the Night. But this helps with that skill of getting back to sleep during the transition of cycles. This will help you both get sleep, and also, will teach them that it's not all fun and games. That this is night and sleep time. You stay strong and you'll both be back on track soon. You got this! ❤️
F

Y'all I need some serious help. I have no idea what is wrong with my LO. She's 7 mo and is now having issues with her not taking good naps. Here's a couple things that make me question what it could be :

1) she's at the age of being needy but bedtime is still normal (she sleeps through the night)
2) I recently sprayed painted in my bathroom and I've been suffering with congestion from the fumes (I wore a mask, she was nowhere near where i was painting but she seems congested as well and will cough even when she's asleep)
3) I had recently given her carrots with cauliflower baby food at dinner (during this nap she seemed to be in pain and kept passing gas and would clench up)

She's currently sleeping on my chest because naps have been like 20 minutes.

What do you think it is?! Help!!

comments.text: Could be a sleep regression. She could just be gassy, give her some mylicon after giving her something that could make her gassy before a nap! See if that makes a different. My daughter is also not having very good naps! Not due to gas, I’m guessing teething, or just not wanting to miss life around her

She’s also right at the age of separation anxiety if I’m not mistaken. That could be part of it.

Tonight she skipped the last nap because I was working and her dad thought she already had slept enough (she slept 10pm to 4, ate and then 4 to 9am but she was still sleepy, spent like 15 mim awake and felt back to sleep until 11 am. That is normal.on her. So tonight I put her to sleep as usual but after 15 min she wakes up screaming like she was in pain, horribly and continously just screaming. After she settled a bit but still screams less and with quiet moments, but is very active taking my hand and moving her leg non stop like you see in the video. The room was dark but I turn the light on to be able.to record the video, and she was actually less active because she saw the phone
Is this a sleep regression? I worried about the continous repetitive movement , what is that?

comments.text: Your baby appears to be a normal human and just doing normal baby things. Sometimes we overthink things. If their anything wrong it can be normal baby stuff, teething, sleep regression, growth spurts, gas, over stimulated, under stimulated. Babies do they own things, sometimes they may oversleep or under sleep.

Mines just started doing this at 5 months too, but atm he’s very overtired and wired because he wasn’t getting enough naps so I put it down to that, could be wind though because he’s a windy baby too, it’s so hard to tell.

Mine started doing it around 5 months too. He rolls his head side to side and sometimes keeps hitting his leg..I read that sometimes repetitive movements when tired is a self soothing technique!

Today I knew my baby was tired but he was fighting it/trying to self soothe and I laid next to him and basically just pretended to sleep and about 5 minutes later of doing those movements and touching my face he was out for hours 😂
She’s out of her loop, just give her Lots Of love and cuddles 🥰 so she knows it’s time for bed.
How long has it been going on? She might just be going through a growth spurt, my son did the same thing for a few days

They are getting all kinds of muscle in their legs and arms getting ready to meet more milestones. I remember thinking the same thing at that age but the doctor said they’re just leaning to use their extremities and the movement is rather jerky for a few months. They get even more wiggly as time progresses. Mine is 8 months and we get lots of kicking and arm waving that usually results in self hitting…but she’s getting ready to crawl and picking things up with her two fingers.

comments.text: While I understand them updating and everything, I’ve read elsewhere that weighted sleep stuff is not particularly safe on younger babies. The suffocation and all of that of course the rules for thing along those lines yes is 100% provable. I was just reading a study last month that the cause of SIDS has recently been linked to an issue in some babies brains at birth that lacks a specific aspect to wake them when they’re in a deep sleep. A deficiency basically and that they’re looking into ways to test for this when babies are born before they leave the hospital and if they’re missing this they are also trying to come up with some sort of way to supplement it so that SIDS doesn’t have a chance to occur. Of course all of those things will take time to develop but they now actually have something solid to go off of to try and to actually fix the issue. In the article it also said because this discovery has been made, parents who have had a baby die of SIDS can stop blaming themselves for it because it’s nothing they did or used that caused it.

Good morning mommas; One tired mother here 🥴( she turned 5 months on saturday)
She was a good sleeper until im assuming 4 month regression. Lol We gave the Ferber method a try last night and it worked okay….
My question is.
Lets say we do checks 3min. 5 min, 10 min, 10 min
What happens after the 4th check in if she don’t stop crying. ?
WE put her to bed at 6:50pm by 7:40ish she fell asleep. She woke up then at 12;00am did the same 3,5,10,10 she fell asleep until 1:10am
Then she woke up and the 3,5,10,10 did not work. We got past the last 4th check in and she continued to cry. At this point it was 2:13am.
So she’s been crying for an hour at this point.
I know it says to continue this until 5-7am but I wanted some sleep so bad I took her into my bed. ☹️ I don’t want to do this again today ( NIGHT 2) so i would love some tips ? Hopefully this makes sense I’m tired and getting ready for work 🥲 lol

text: My 10 week old cannot connect sleep cycles during naps. He consistently wakes up 40 minutes after falling asleep, and I don’t know how to help him get back to sleep. He’s clearly tired still, but if I leave him alone, he grunts and wiggles and cries until he’s wide awake. If I pick him up to rock and soothe him back to sleep, he’ll calm down until he realizes he’s starting to fall asleep… then he thrashes his head around to wake himself back up. A lactation consultant said try to nurse him between sleep cycles, but I really don’t want to create a ”nurse to sleep” association. Any tips?? Do I just have to wait til 4 months to try to sleep train?

comments.text: Same here! Our girl is 6 weeks and has been having cat naps lately. She sleeps for no more than 45 minutes, sometimes less. I usually try and take her for a walk a couple of times a day so she gets a couple extra naps in. I know she’s tired but she seems to fight it mostly unless she’s up with me, although at night she sleeps excellent. (Knock on wood)
Mine is almost 4 months and wakes up 30 minutes. But she wakes up happy. So now I’ve just made peace with it. Hopefully after this sleep regression it’ll get better.

Same situation here 🙋🏻‍♀️
I would hold my son & when he fell asleep I would finally put him down. But lately we’ve been trying to put him down drowsy but awake to help him connect his sleep cycles. We also tap him lightly to let him know we’re there but once he cries we’d pick him up and try again.

It could also be baby feeling overstimulated before settling for nap time. We keep play time to a minimum so we don’t overstumulate. We walk around the house holding him to settle him down a bit and it seemed to help as well.

My now 4mo has been exactly like this since 6 weeks - even though he falls asleep independently! Apparently cat napping is normal until around 5-6minths but we have persisted with trying to resettle for some naps and it is occasionally successful. He is getting less resistant to resettling now and will sometimes connect his cycles if we use white noise. It was a huge pain tho as he would sometimes need 5 naps in the day and always cranky at bedtime 😆

Babies are starting to see the world they wanna be up and look at things lol so nap time is usually hard, my baby sleeps great at night, but during day it takes extra to get him down and sometimes we just get a 30 min nap until the next feed then we try and start it over

First off, HE IS SOOO HANDSOME 😍🥰

And my boy is the same way. 11 weeks old and will not nap during the day longer than about 40 minutes. He does take multiple naps a day and sleeps well at night. Average sleep at night is 5-8 hours, so I can't complain here.

comments.text: My 7 almost 8 week old won’t nap during the day without being held. It can be really difficult. I baby wear a lot and put her down occasionally while she sleeps. She sleeps better at night time with her fleece sleep sack in her bassinet.

Usually around 5 months. Depends on the baby. But 10 weeks is much too early. Hang in there, he will eventually nap longer.

text: Ask Moms Anything

Hi All, FTM. I joined this group because I needed sleeping tips for my 4 month old. When he was a newborn, he suffered with colic so I spent many nights with him screaming in pain. I was exhausted and I would end up crying my eyes out thinking I was doing something wrong. I just kept hearing it will get better or you think this is bad now, sometimes it goes on for months. I had so many plans before he was born of what i wouldn't do, I wanted to sleep train, he would never sleep in my bed, he will be independent and sleep on his own. All that went out the window bc he never liked being swaddled and didn't sleep long on his back. Due to his colic and gas, I walked him constantly to soothe him, and he ended up sleeping in bed with me. I even bought the cosleeper cot for him to sleep in my bed. At this stage, my little one takes naps during the day...I can't give you a schedule. At night he wakes up and feeds at any point, it feels like every 2 mins. I would like for him to sleep through the night. But my point is, and in reading all the posts and positive comments...Moms you are doing your best and don't think you are failing. Do not compare yourself to those that have best sleeping babies. Every baby is different, and we need to acknowledge that it's okay. Love and cuddle your crying babies, lack of sleep won't be forever. Once your baby is healthy and happy and you are doing your best, be proud that that baby can hold onto you and give you the sweetest hugs. Praying for us all to have a full night's sleep.

comments.text: Exactly what we all need to read ❤️❤️ thank you for your honest words, nothing can describe the enormity of our roles as mums/parents. Honestly amongst each other is invaluable. We’ve got this 💪🏻

After a little over a week of it, he only woke up once! I even had to make sure he was breathing cause I was use to him waking up every 2 hours! Mines also 4 months

Then she has her bath @ 7, right into a dim room with white noise on. Get PJs on and then I nurse her to sleep (works for us, I know lots will say this is a big no no)

I follow the French parenting style. The book “bringing up Bebe “ is a great book to read for fun and for parenting. I use “wait it out” instead of cry it out and he was sleeping through the night a week after I got the book. He’s now 4 months and sleeps through the night (except the last week for the 4 month regression/
growth spurt)

Nandita Roy anything specific?? We have a ton 😅

When we get up we immediately get dressed, eat, and play. When it’s time for naps I change her bottom, put on a sleep sac, sound machine, and light off. After 10 minutes of rocking, she goes in her crib and typically sleeps for an hour and a half. That is repeated throughout the day. For bed time, we read a story, bath, lotion, sleeper, sleep sac, sound machine, and small lamp, and a bottle. After she eats and burps, I rock for 10 min and lay her in crib.

The picture is our current schedule. I’d HIGHLY recommend picking up the moms on call book. There were a ton of helpful tips and routine ideas to help.

comments.text: Our second baby loved the Merlin sleep suit. We had two and also the next size up, which he didn’t really need at that point. comments.text: That sleep rock is been re called don't let her sleep there. Also keep trying with the crib or the bassinet ...she will not get used to the first day...kept trying for week weeks. Also you can try a sleepy sack she might like it.

text:
I was hesitate to post as i was afraid of being kind of told off after reading some of the comments but I am looking for encouragement and some support and advise ...
First time mum to a rainbow baby boy after multiple losses hence maybe that's why I am too soft and have this attachment to my son after all trauma I endured .

My son sleeps with me in bed since he was born. Is there any of you who is the same I can not be the only one ?

So before I get to sleep training I need to work on getting him to sleep in his own cot. His cot is attached to my bed ! He is now over 3 months old. Everytime I would put him down he will cry to be picked up. He hates to be on his back. If he is already asleep in my arms after I transfer him he wakes up after few min and cry . The longest I get to have him asleep in the cot was maybe 30 min. Moro reflex wakes him up or when he spit the dummy or as soon as he realised where he is .At night neither of us was getting sleep so after a week of trying I gave up as I dont really mind having him in my bed but I know for a near future I would want him to sleep in his own cot on his own and it will be much harder because of the habit of sleeping with me .
While he is sleeping with me he is so easy ... never cries wakes for food eat (i breastfeed on demand ) I Burp him then I change his nappy and he is going straight back to sleep.
But my goal is to have him sleeping on his own in the cot and in near future in his own crib.
I will have a lot work to do so I am open for any advice . Thank you

comments.text: Hes beautiful!!! I'm sorry for your loss and I completely understand your concern. we co sleep, it can be done safely. Dont apologize, do what works for you and your family. Be safe and soak up the snuggles. I can say I don't sleep well with my LO in bed, but he does and thats all that matters to me.

I co slept and still do my boy is 6 months, took a while to get pregnant so I feel this is why I have chose this route but recently trying to get him to sleep in his crib.. maybe try side lying? Roll a relieving blanket behind him so he doesn't roll back.. thats how my son loves to sleep! He also has reflux issues and was told to elevate the one end of the bed so it doesn't bug him as much. Good luck and beautiful baby!

We are co sleepers with both my girls and I tell you what they sleep great and I well sleep better knowing they are right next to me and safe. Do what works best for you and baby. Co sleeping can be done safely. Sorry for ur loss I can only imagine how much pain you went through. Your baby boy is absolutely beautiful 💙

replies.text: Amber Kersey can you give a few more details on safe cosleeping... co sleeping is not something i thought id do but now weve started and i get so scared and nervous sometimes!

Amber Kersey I co sleep with my daughter and have since day 1 cus she refused her bassinet . You’re not alone. ❤️. Sleep training is for infants at start LEASt 4.5 months-6 month or older— most babies just don’t have the capacity to self soothe before 6 months . “9 months In- 9 months On” 14 yrs ago I co-slept with my baby until he was at least 6 months old. We started off with naps in his crib and eventually started sleep training 9 months. I’ve got a new 8 month old who still wakes up every 2-4 hrs; at around 4-5am we bring him into the bed til we’re ready to be up. He just sleeps better cuddled, and that’s ok for now. Trust your mumma instincts, you’re baby will tell you when ready, and you’ll know when to “put your foot down” and hold your ground. Best thing you can start doing now is get a regular routine; if you have a willing partner include them in the nighttime routine, that way they too can help out crying baby down (all too often, mom becomes the routine and dads/partners can’t console baby). If you do have a bassinet/cot is put baby down drowsy, not quite yet asleep; stay and assure ( if needed) baby you’re there, but let him learn to ‘fall asleep’ that last 5% on his own. You’re doing great— don’t stress too much about wake windows, strict regiments, etc. keep your routine and know it’s ok to flex if needed, things will fall back into place. 🥰
I would love to help you get him to sleep independently. Is he 3 or 4 months?

Sleep consultant here! Congrats on your rainbow 🌈 baby!!! He’s adorable.

Unfortunately for some babies sleep training and crib sleeping can’t be separated. Meaning.. in order to make that transition to his crib there will be protest. It’s a change that he’s not used to. His brain makes strong associations by this age so there will be some drama as you are changing that. But that’s not a bad thing!!! And that doesn’t mean your attachment will be shaken. In fact, In order for your baby to build a secure attachment he will need to be away from you, bc the wrestling with those emotions of mom not there then the reunification builds that secure attachment. It takes just a few nights at this young age. But for fairness for him you have to remove everything that his brain has formed an association with. Otherwise you won’t see the crying decrease. So pacifier, swaddle, nursing to sleep, nursing til drowsy, rocking, co sleeping etc. If he’s still reliant on something like getting drowsy while feeding then when he wakes his his brain goes right back to that association. If you don’t give it there will be a lot of crying night after night, without the progress. If you do give it then it will reinforce the sleep association and cause more wakings. I hope I’m making sense!!! So here’s your goal… follow eat, play, sleep during the day with 1.5-1.75 hr wake windows. Bedtime move feed to the beginning of the routine… feed first keeping wide awake. Then bath, pjs, book and lay him in the crib wide awake. Then use a sleep training method to handle the crying consistently until he is asleep. I would also move the crib much farther from your bed. I know that’s scary but babies tend to wake more often the closer they are to mom, instead of emerging from a sleep cycle going right into a new one.

comments.text: Our pediatrician gave us the okay not wake to eat once we were back at birth weight. I believe at our 2 week appt we didn’t need to wake anymore. Typically I take those nights that she wakes as a sign she’s going through a leap, or growth spurt and needing extra food.

If he sleeps, I would let him if there no health issues.
Otherwise, if he wakes to eat, especially at this age, I would feed. More like 8-9 months did I stop overnight feedings. Around 6m plus you can see is more that time.

text:
First time mom here asking for any help!

Our 7 week old has bad reflux and is on medication from the Dr which seems to be helping slightly. He will sleep in his car seat, swing, and of course peoples arms but as soon as we lay him down we maybe get 20 minutes before he is screaming. Typically he has spit up next to him in the crib and needs to be burped. You can tell laying flat is causing his discomfort. I have tried to incline the mattress but he was rolling to his stomach which caused me to much stress and concern and did not seem to be helping. He is bottle fed breast milk with Dr Browns colic/ reflux bottles and burped at least every 2 oz of not more often. We have tried to keep him upright after eating for long periods of time and that doesn’t seem to make a difference. He is also on Gerber Good Start probiotic drops as well.

Any help or tips are greatly appreciated our sweet boy is exhausted and so are we, looking for some comfortable sleep for the entire family!

comments.text: My son was the same. He was diagnosed with silent reflux at about 7 weeks old and he is on omeprazole twice a day. We give it to him 30 minutes before the 1st and last bottle of the day, it's important not to just give it and feed straight away. I also did a specific baby massage nightly after his bath to help with colic/wind and use Dr Brown narrow neck bottles. He has been seeing a paediatric osteo which has been amazing, such improvement. She also picked up that he had a tongue and lip tie which we had lasered 4 weeks ago. He is now 4.5 months old and is so much better. Those first 7 weeks were absolutely horrible. He will likely go off the medication at 6 months old after a review by the Dr.

Add Gelmix infant thickener! It changed our sons reflux along with his medication! Adding cerial did not help and would not make it thick enough. Also if his bottle was heated a bit more warm than the norm it helped as well. I read reflux babies do better with warmer bottles and his doctor confirmed

Following cause same
Chiropractor helped but it’s bad again. He cries the whole time.
I’ve cut out dairy now hoping that will help

replies.text: Danielle Roets cutting dairy helped significantly for me! It's a bummer she may have a milk allergy, but such a relief to find something that works!

comments.text: You are literally doing everything you can do for your LO. I Would suggest that maybe you should see an osteopath at this point. My son was exactly the same but thankfully Omeprazole worked for him and then at 5 months we started weaning and so we took him off omeprazole and he was fine so he had grew out of it. It’s very very hard and I know how exhausted you must be but I promise you, things will get better, just hang in there xx

Nexiam helped alot!!!!!
Also dip my babies dummy in gaviscon and also helps.
I turn my baby on his side to sleep and put small cushions around hom that he can't turn.
Let him suck on his dummy when he is put to sleep the constant swallowing helps.

This helped for my baby. But honestly Nexiam worked sooo good

My son had this issue. They gave him Omeprazole. We feed him and burp him but we give him 20-30 mins in our arms before laying him down. It gives his food time to settle and digest a bit. Hes had this issue since he was born and is almost three months. It's worked so far. Dr said they usually out grow it by six months

My son had similar problems when he was this age I found what helped him was having little bit of warm water which settled his tummy and ruhuger in his bottle worked well for him might help you. I also switched him to colic and contapation aptimil formula it's a bit more of a thinner formula and is made to settle the tummy.

Following. We are going through the same exact thing with our LO. He is also 7 weeks and I just don’t know what else to do. I haven’t put him on meds yet as we will be seeing the doctor next week after changing Peds. Last Ped said he was ok. No he is now 🤦‍♀️😭. Praying this is over all of us soon.

replies.text: Yanira Rodriguez I’m sorry! Best of luck at the new Pediatrician

comments.text:

I was using mylicon drops along with gripe water. I tried the raised mattress keeping her upright, burping etc. EVERYTHING! I just recently switched to the avent bottles and she absolutely loves them! She has been doing much better and we even stopped with all the drops. Only use them when needed! I swear by the bottles!

We also used a thickener in our bottles to help with the spit up, so that combined with meds and elevation was the best we could do. They do grow out of it, but it is so hard waiting for it to happen. Finger's crossed bubs gets some relief soon x

I had the same problem mama, but when my daughter was maybe 3 weeks old (she’s 6 now).
For a couple weeks all we could do was put her on our tummy and get her to sleep.. we took turns 😕

I started feeding her in a side lying position and made her sleep in propped to her side. I used to watch her like a Hawk all night as that was the only position she’d sleep in other than contact napping. I also worked on controlling my fast letdown and that eased the gassiness.
Since last week, she sleeps and naps not just on her back but also by herself.

I am not sure if my daughter is dealing with a lot of reflux but the side lying position worked wonders for me.
Good luck mama ❤️

Cut out dairy and all foods that induce reflux, so you eat as if you have reflux yourself if BF. It helps a lot. Holding baby up for 30 min after each feed and making sure you get good burps out.
Meds if needed, talk to pediatrician. This swaddle go’s around crib mattress which makes it safer to have them more on an incline.

Hey, I haven’t used them but hear great things about Tresillian. You can go there and they help you with the sleeping and other things. They have been around for years. My mum went there when I was a baby as she was struggling with feeding and sleeping (triplets), she swears by them and I’ve heard heaps of other women praise them. If you don’t want to go into a centre they have other options, but you would probably benefit from a visit. Good luck and all the best!

rg.au/

My son is the same way on medication I use a slight incline nothing major come to find out on top of reflux due to me eating dairy he has a dairy intolerance which amplified his reflux more so I’ve cut dairy and he is so much happier and so is his little belly!!

replies.text: Rebecca Rader I do not eat much dairy and pump so I combine the milk then make bottles so I don’t think that would be enough dairy but I started cutting it out as of this week. I’ll try anything to help! Thank you, glad it’s working for your son and giving him relief

Taryn Overton if you do half breast and half formula maybe a hypoallergenic one would be a good try. My son has had that issue and once we changed things around he has been so much better with soothing and relaxing since he hasn’t had acid reflux due to being on nutramigen hypoallergenic (off brand works fine too) and I cut dairy out and only eat it here and there) still trying to expose him to the allergen but not at and amplified rate if that makes sense. Just think of it as if it were to cause you reflux it’s something your baby could get from breast milk and thinking of it that way has helped me so much. Mine usually gets breast milk occasionally formula but once we switched to hypoallergenic and I cut dairy it has been a game changer along with his acid reflux medication right before bathtime to give it enough time to kick in. I hope you and your little one get some relief. Reflux is common. Mommas are strong you’ll make it through!

comments.text: My son had reflux as well as a cows milk allergy. He was put on a specialty formula as well as Famotidine twice a day, as well as the Gerber soothe probiotics. Helped some but not enough. Make sure your track your little ones symptoms and stay on it with the doctors. My son ended up having to get a ultra sound to rule out Pyloric stenosis, thankfully he was only have pyloric stenosis flare ups and not chronic. With a medication change he’s now 5 1/2 months and finally doing better. Hang in there mama reflux is hard on mama and baby!
It can take at least 10 days for the reflux meds to start working. I know in the hospital we were told to give our DD some thickener before every feed which also seemed to help. 🤞
Try using this. My daughter had the same issue until we try this! It really has mad our lives way easier.

My baby was like this. I eventually had to cut dairy & soy. He had the silent reflux and would sometimes wake up coughing on acid. It broke my heart so bad.

I hate to say it but I had him sleep on a boppy pillow beside me in a bedside bassinet so he could be propped up. It was the only way he could breathe well enough to sleep. It was terrifying but he was okay. He’s 6 months now, a belly sleeper, free from dairy & soy, & still on his acid meds to help. He never has trouble anymore.

One thing my doctor said too is you can take receiving blankets and roll them up hot dog style and kinda wrap them into a U underneath the bed sheet. Then you can prop him up on the top of the U on and inclined mattress and that can help but it’s not something that’s gonna get stuffed right into his face.

I've found that having my daughter lay on her tummy on my chest helped a lot but straight up on my shoulder she'd spit up or throw up but on my chest on her tummy she never did... maybe try that and lay slightly inclined. I also gave gripe water, gas drops and also biogaia probiotic her pediatrician recommended that specific brand. Amazon carries it. I hope this helps.

My girl is 7 weeks, also on Pepcid. I’m doing a dairy free diet. I keep her upright for 20 mins after a feed. She only takes 2-3 ounces a feed. So I burp every 1 ounce. Maybe cut back the amount she is eating in total each session? Might be too much volume for her stomach?

Same we are going into 7 weeks. What has helped us is switching to premie nipples with our dr brown bottles. It helped slow the feed down and we noticed less spit up from just switching up the nipples

My son was the same- I just stopped trying to crib train until his digestive system was a little more developed. He’s 11 weeks tomorrow and we still sleep on the recliner together. It’s the only way I get chunks of sleep and I know he feels best this way. My son does, however, sleep in his crib for naps during the day tho.

My daughter was prescribed medication which I wasn’t too happy about giving but she was in such a state I had no choice.
I spoke to my health visitor who told me to just try going dairy free for a week and see.
I did dairy free, stopped her meds, and her “reflux” improved massively and I was able to lie her flat after feeds within three weeks.

Maybe worth a try, I had no idea dairy could affect breast milk so much
The chiropractor helped wonders!! But its not for everyone I understand that but im a big believer and what a difference it made!!

text:

Hi mommies!

FTM here and it's the middle of the night bc I'm dying 😭 My son turns 4 months next week and we started to sleep train. He's started to roll over both ways so he's in the nested bean sleep sack and we also took both the arms off tonight as well. If I'm losing sleep I might as well knock out two birds with one stone 😂

Wake Windows: typically around 1.5-2 hours and right before bed is 2 hours almost on the dot

Background: Takes medicine daily for acid reflux and sleeps in the crib full time except for one contact nap a day (I love the baby cuddles 🥰) He also gets no screen time.

Feedings: Formula fed with baby oatmeal in his milk for his acid reflux since the beginning 3 months old.

Sleep Routine: Sleeps with black out curtains, humidifer with lavender, sleep machine, does bedtime routine (bath, lotion, book, sleep sack, feeding, and a little play if he's not tired yet) Sleep/Nap times are usually 1-1.5 hours during the day each nap and one good 2 hour nap. Sometimes it can be 45 mins.

Tonight we started sleep training and I'm a little lost on if I'm doing everything right. I waited for his sleeping cues before I put him down. When he went down to sleep roughly around 8:45-9pm, he slept for 2-2.5 hours before he woke up and ever since then is waking up every hour. His first time going to bed, I said good night, put the paci in, and left. He did not cry and fell asleep on his own. After that, he's trying to self soothe but gets very frustrated because the paci will fall out of his mouth but once that's in when I check on him after a little crying he'll go back to sleep but will wake up an hour again later. Also, please don't comment and say to not start until 6 months and that it's not appropriate, because either way I'm starting now 🤷🏻‍♀️

Questions:

1: Do I let him cry for 15 mins or so before I just put the paci back in his mouth? Because that's really all he needs and will go back to sleep during the night- I've been waiting 15-20 mins but I'm not sure if I should put it in before that time for him to self soothe.

2: Is sleep training at night different/easier than daytime naps?

3: If the paci falls back out right after I leave do I go and put it right back in or do I let him cry more?

4: How long does it take before he stop waking up every hour to be put back to sleep?

5: is there anything that I'm missing? Any advice helps!

So I just sleep trained my four month old as he was waking up every 30 mins to an hour wanting his paci all night long! I couldn’t handle it any longer!
The first few nights were really rough! I would do night routine feed him his bottle and put him down and give him his binkie. The first few nights, he cried and cried! It was horrible but now he sleeps through the whole night and puts himself back to sleep. For about the first week to two he would wake up for so long in the middle of the night trying sooth that he ended up hungry and I would feed him but after two weeks he didn’t need that anymore.
I personally did the extinction Ferber method as my son just got more upset when I would come in!
From what I’ve read, you want to go in for at most 1 minute, pat/rub them, and say you’re there then leave. I didn’t give my son his binkie as that was the biggest habit we were trying to break with sleep training. He needed to learn another way to get soothed, as the goal was for him to sleep on his own without my assistances.
Momma you do what works best for you! Your gut will tell you what feels right and doesn’t! 😊

text:
Hi all! I got a question. I am following cara babies and am trying to practice my daughters self soothing (she’s 8 weeks). What is most important right now is putting her in her crib (I have a cot nearby where I’m with her) since for the the past two months she literally has slept on me. She hates the swaddle- she will be ok during CRIES, but within 15 minutes she is angry after putting her down. So, I got the Merlin sleeper. Question: do I rock her and feed her in it and then put her down? When I go to pick her up to comfort and put her back to sleep, she’s always in it, right?? I know it’s a silly question, but it’s so bulky 😂.
I start grad school again and working, and she is starting to roll to her side, that I really am just wanting to make sure she is in a safe place. For those that had co-sleepers on them, did it take long for them to adjust? I’m nervous! My first was a dream and slept through the night with little help at 2 months and was a natural at falling asleep on his own. My little girl is a fighter to stay on mom. During the day, fine- but night I want her to be safe. Thanks in advance!

comments.text: My baby would not sleep in the Merlin sleep suit, so we purchased a dreamland weighted swaddle and it has been a game changer!!! As far as your question is yes I would rock, feed, and comfort her while she is wearing it and then put her down.

text:
Hello, I need help or suggestions or anything that may help our situation. We are at a loss on what to do. We have 2 daughters 11 months and 3.5 years. 11 month old sleeps in our room in her own crib. 3.5 year old has her own room. We have a crib in girls room as they share a room but we cannot move 11 month old in until the toddler sleeps through the night.

So the 3.5 year old used to sleep wonderfully and through the night no problems. But something changed the last few months to where she wakes anywhere from 2-4 times a night. She will walk across the house to our room where we immediately take her back to her room and to bed every time. She did this when she took an afternoon nap so we stopped naps to see if she needed to be more tired but nope still waking without naps too. I feel like now it has become a habit wake up and I don’t know how to break it when she just gets up and comes to our room. We did have a baby gate keeping her in her room but she has figured out how to unlock it and really when the gate was there she would just scream and cry waking the house up until someone would come. Sometimes she says she is scared, sometimes she wants water, other times she wants nothing. She sleeps with a glow warm to help when she wants a little light, we sprays air freshener that we pretend is bad guy spray every night, we keep water in her room for when she is thirsty to try and get her to stay in her room and sleep but nothing is working. We don’t know what to do. If you have any suggestions anything is welcome!!!

Cuddling is good for their mental and emotional health honestly and one day they won't want to anymore and we will miss it so enjoy it while it last.

I heard it described as "imagine ypu fall asleep at night in your bed and then one day ypu wake up in the front yard, you'd be disoriented and confused and possibly scared, if after a few nights in a row of this happening ypu might eventually fear going to sleep at all for fear that you'll wake in the front yard again". That really struck me about how and why babies wake suddenly and upset sometimes if they get transferred to a different place after falling asleep. Mine seems to do ok with it, she would fall asleep in my arms and then I would put her in her basinet next to the bed and she would wake but was never upset by it. I've started having her sleep all night between me and my husband bc she can stand up in thw badinet and I'm worried sge will fall out of it or knock it over. I'm figuring she will sleep with us a little longer before we transition her to her crib.

I hold my 2 month old for 20-30 mins then put him in his bassinet to make sure he’s really sleeping before!
We’ll see what the months ahead have for us but it works

replies.text: Gina Dugan this is what we do too & it works for us! My girl is 4 months old

I was told that the way babies fall sleep is the way they think they’ll wake up, so if they wake up differently they can’t go back to sleep. I don’t know if I’m 100% right. The same goes with rocking them or feeding them to sleep. So if you co-sleep and then lay them on their own, they will wake up looking for you. I hope that helps!

I personally can't sleep well when he is in bed because I'm too nervous he'll fall out or my husband will roll over him, so I always put him to bed.

i think self soothing should be a very last resort. i know it is so freaking hard to be a mom and sometimes things are just so overwhelming. but it’s hard to be a baby too.. they lived in us for several months. there was never a quiet moment because they were always at least listening to our heart beats. they were always held close to mom, they were warm, safe, fed 24/7. it will take a while before they can get into the groove of things. the BEST soothing method is to be there for them. even when you’ve got things to do, places to be, people to see, your baby needs you more.. hold them close, rock them and tell them you love them, sing to them, give them soft kisses and comforting touches. after you’ve tried everything and you’re feeling upset, that’s when you set baby down and go take a moment to yourself to ensure you’re in the good head space to care for your little. at the end of the day, you all are doing great and that’s what matters!!!

replies.text: Ellie Smith Hello. I’m at this point. About the start something! Anything! My question is, how did you stop her standing up and crying? Every time we leave, that’s all she does. TIA

Alex Louise so I put her down obviously when she’s showing signs of being tired. Say goodnight give her a cuddle and lay her down, then leave the room. Inevitably she will cry. Then go in after 5 mins IF she’s still crying, lie her back down and give her her comforter back, then leave again and wait 10 mins then 15.. the main thing is to keep the vibe positive and calm when you go in. And only go in at those time intervals if she’s crying. Avoid direct eye contact and only say things like ‘shh bedtime now’. That’s what I’ve done anyway.
The first night she cried for 25 minutes so I intervened twice.
The second night, 8 mins.
The 3rd night , 3 minutes
And the 4th and 5th night only an initial cry when I put her down but by the time I’ve left the room and sat back down, she’s soundo. Hope that helps! Xx
Alex Louise also patience ! Lots and lots of patience! Every baby is different x

comments.text:
Honestly, I know a lot of parents are against it (and some believe in it - to each their own!) but I let my son cry ir out because he usually self soothes himself after 10/15 minutes. (I’m right outside the door and if he’s screaming bloody murder I go in asap). I have to do this because at our home we have blackout blinds and I have black towels tacked up on each side for optimal darkness but when he’s at my parents (every Saturday) my mom has 8ft high windows in her bedroom (where he sleeps at night/ naps during the day) and it’s bright as heck. I couldn’t even nap in there on a sunny day, and the sun goes down between 8/9pm. So when he’s there he cries ir out to self soothe.
Again I know this method isn’t for everyone and we don’t let him go too long if he’s really crying but it has helped him with naps at my parents and he’s learned to self soothe because of it. He’s a year old and off formula (couldn’t breastfeed) and on whole milk so I usually give him a 4 oz bottle before his morning nap and 4oz before his afternoon nap and that helps too! He also gets an 8oz bottle before bedtime and one when he wakes up in the morning.
Again - not for everyone! Try different things and you’ll learn what works best for you and your babe. Honestly it’s mostly a trial and error game. But you’ll find out what works best for you!
They will learn at their own pace how to self soothe or they may not at all, every baby is different.

text: How did you wean your baby off night feeds? We're down to one feed at about 4am (with a dream feed at 10pm).

comments.text: Following. I'm at this stage too. Our girl fully wakes at 230am like clockwork. Not sure if she's waking bc she's truly hungry or just out of habit.

replies.text: Meagan Gardner mine would wake up at 1 habitually, then 3 out of hunger. So my husband would respond at 1am. It took about a week for Baby to realize that he wasn't getting the boob, so he just gave up and slept. 😂 He would then only wake out of hunger.

comments.text: Just reallocated some of that feed into the daytime feeds. So let's say you feed 120ml bottle at 4am, then increase daytime bottles by 30ml each and drop the 4am feed. Of course it also depends on the age. When they are still very little they can't handle such big bottles, but as they get bigger then it's possible. We dropped one of two night feeds probably around 4-5 months of age and still do a dreamfeed at around midnight before going to bed now at almost 8 months of age.

replies.text: Liana Taylor he's feeding on the breast and not the bottle, so I don't know how to increase his feeds unless I do it more frequently. As it is, he feeds about every 2 to 2 1/2 hours. Also started solids this week.
